column4: one last question, what would you think about using 2.6.21 (ubuntu kernel dont remember the release) and the iptables version of its release as hardware router? would it be good even though its outdated?
mind if i ask you why it would be bad?
cause it's not made for a router at all and very outdated and by now pretty certainly prone to exploits
my actual router uses 2.6.20 (although not ubuntu i386) do i have to worry? lol

no. cause the vendor of your router might (and should have) patched it properly. the ubuntu one is by now probably !EOL and not patched anymore. also ubuntu is a general purpose distro. router distros are differently made
vendor is linksys and they have last patched it in march 2010, you still say i can sleep tight?
basically, you can run ubuntu as a "hardware router", but if you have to ask about it, you really shouldn't do it
I don't know how linksys makes their router but you can sleep better than with a ubuntu install from 2010 as a router imho
what is the reason you want to use ubuntu for a router? just for routing alone, it can't be?
just for routing yeah, thought i may have a better control of it if i wasnt bound to the manufacturer
if you want that buy a cheap openwrt compatible router. your ubuntu router will probably cost more electricity in a year than such a dedicated small routerbox
that makes alot of sence thanks
WR1043ND is very cheap, runs openwrt
in europe there are. fritz!box by avm. it's a phonesystem, dsl modem and router. runs linux and has free firmware available via freetz and some very select models via openwrt
